<!-- 1. Log in to that site as an administrator. -->
<!-- 2. Go to Tools: Import in the WordPress admin panel. -->
<!-- 3. Install the "WordPress" importer from the list. -->
<!-- 4. Activate & Run Importer. -->

<!-- 6. You will first be asked to map the authors in this export file to users -->

		<title>9Marks-logo</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/9marks-logo/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 07 Jun 2018 18:36:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/9Marks-logo.png</guid>

		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>142</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2018-06-07 18:36:22]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2018-06-07 18:36:22]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>

		<title>Sermon - The Audacity of Hope - Foundations</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/sermon-the-audacity-of-hope-foundations/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 17 Dec 2018 18:39:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/12/Sermon-The-Audacity-of-Hope-Foundations.mp3</guid>

		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA["Sermon - The Audacity of Hope - Foundations".]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>169</wp:post_id>

					<item>
		<title>front page</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/may-2020/front-page-3/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 29 Apr 2020 23:58:32 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/front-page.pdf</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<title>Newsletter 2020 Sept Back page</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/september-2020/newsletter-2020-sept-back-page/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 02 Sep 2020 13:00:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>

					<item>
		<title>DR0000_0228_1</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/sermon/jesus-alone/dr0000_0228_1/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Oct 2020 13:01:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>

		<title>DR0000_0234_1</title>

					<item>
		<title>I Will Quietly Wait</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/sermon/yet-i-will-quietly-wait/i-will-quietly-wait/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Sep 2021 02:17:52 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/09/I-Will-Quietly-Wait.m4a</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA["I Will Quietly Wait".]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>798</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2021-09-02 02:17:52]]></wp:post_date>

		</wp:postmeta>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|media_object_image|0|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|media_object_content|0|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|partial_reveal|0|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|page_header_reveal|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|page_header_image|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|page_header_content|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|full_width_reveal|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|full_width_content|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[<p>Christian churches are in decline in every corner of our land. Mainline denominations have been especially hard hit, and ours - the Southern Baptist Convention – certainly is not immune. Despite being the largest Protestant denomination in the United States and boasting over 15 million members, our denomination is being refined, little by little, even in our community of Louisville, Kentucky. We hear it; we see it; we feel it.</p><p>Statisticians report the reality in plain and harsh language; 3 of 4 SBC churches have plateaued, are in accelerating decline, or are in the process of dying. Many are already gone. Such numbers rattle our confidence, shake our security, sharpen our resolve. As His Believers, we are called to contend for the faith once for all delivered to the Saints (Jude 3). What shall we do?</p><p>In the Book of Revelation, Jesus judges the seven churches as He walks amongst them; He knows them, very intimately. He identifies strengths, weaknesses, and draws conclusions to challenge their healthiness and continuance as faithful brides. He is determinedly resolved in exhorting, “He who has an ear, let him hear what the Spirit says to the churches.”</p><p>With awareness of these macro trends, and with confidence that Jesus knows us too, in 2017 the people of Audubon Baptist Church and The Church at Louisville joined together. At that time, Audubon Baptist enjoyed a rich seventy-three year legacy; The Church at Louisville a much shorter four-year life as a church plant. Throughout many months of prayer and counsel, God’s Sovereignty shown brightly, yielding hope and peace as our heart cries for church revitalization were confirmed.</p><p>Today, we picture a future as ONE congregation with a peace that surpasses all understanding. God has been gracious every step of the way; His people have been wonderfully blessed. To God be the glory.</p>]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|full_width_image|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|media_object_reveal|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|media_object_image|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|media_object_content|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|partial_reveal|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>

		</wp:postmeta>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|partials|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>Our Pastors</title>

		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|full_width_content|2|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|full_width_reveal|2|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|events_calendar_title|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|partial_reveal|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[yes]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|slider_object_slides|1|0|_empty]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_crb_content_fields|events_object_reveal|1|0|value]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							<wp:postmeta>

		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This is the WPForms preview page. All your form previews will be handled on this page.</p><p>The page is set to private, so it is not publicly accessible. Please do not delete this page :) .</p>]]></content:encoded>

														</item>
					<item>
		<title>December 2019</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/december-2019/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Dec 2019 20:09:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=380</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"align":"center"} -->
<h3 style="text-align:center"><strong>Praise God, Brought Near!</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em>Ephesians 2:13, But now in Christ Jesus you who once were far off have been brought near&nbsp;by the blood of Christ.</em></strong>&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I stood among the
peoples and suddenly felt small, looked past, pushed, and wholly out of place,
“alienated from the commonwealth of Israel and a stranger to the covenants of
promise” (Ephesians 2:12).&nbsp; The feeling surprised;
I had recently journeyed to Jerusalem with AmyJo to experience the Holy Land,
to walk in the footsteps of Jesus, to be refreshed and renewed in my faith.&nbsp; Frankly, I expected a genuine welcoming to
visit the places sacred to our faith.&nbsp;
Yet, as I stood alongside the Western Wall of the temple, touching the
stones that towered some 60’ above me, wandering among the worshippers and
wailers too, I felt out of place.&nbsp; And
anything but welcomed.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Christians are a
scant minority in much of the Old City.&nbsp;
Still a vibrant and functioning city, within the walls are “quarters”
housing resident Jews, Muslims, Armenians, and a small group of Christians
too.&nbsp; Inside the city where the chosen
people of God gathered through the millennials, edgy faith wars are waged
today.&nbsp; Muslims are at the Jews; Jews are
at the Muslims; everyone is at the Christians.&nbsp;
The place is uncomfortable; it is confrontational and ‘pushy’; frankly,
it is hostile (Eph. 2:14,16).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I paused one
evening as I touched the Western Wall of the temple.&nbsp; The temple, of course, housed God in the days
of the OT.&nbsp; God lived in the temple; those
living near His dwelling-place and having access to Him were His people and
covenant holders of the promise. Israel was near; Gentiles, like me, were far away.&nbsp; Gentiles were without hope and without God.&nbsp; (Eph. 2:12). Such beliefs remain among the
Orthodox even today.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>An overwhelming
sense of sadness enveloped me as I bumped among the worshippers still seeking
the Messiah.&nbsp; People all around,
straining to be close to God, conjuring up just the right emotion, walking
backwards away from the wall to “not turn their backs upon God”, crying out for
the Messiah, and yet wholly missing Him.&nbsp;
I committed afresh to pray for those yet called.&nbsp; May their time be close at hand.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Despite the stark
reality, the trip propelled my faith to higher heights.&nbsp; Certainly, it is wondrous to touch the
2,000-year-old stones from God’s temple, to stand upon the Mount of Olives, to
sit within the Garden of Gethsemane where Jesus spent His final hours, to view
the place where it is said our resurrected Lord departed for Heaven.&nbsp; AmyJo and I shall always remember being together
in those places.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But those sacred
places merely provide the backdrop to Jesus’ earthly ministry, a ministry that
called those far away, like me, to Himself by the gift of grace from a Father
who loves me.&nbsp; Being there and seeing it,
well, I know that it is indeed a most precious gift to be called, beloved, and
kept.&nbsp; I marvel anew that He has brought
me – a sinner - near.&nbsp; I was far off and
now I am near.&nbsp; It is beyond my
understanding.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>May we all marvel
afresh at the gift of grace given to us though our Lord and Savior Jesus
Christ; and may we continue also in prayer for those everywhere without such
hope, in Jerusalem and Louisville too.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>He is worthy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastor Jeff Akin</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":377,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Pg-1-DEC-2019.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Pg-1-DEC-2019.pdf">Pg 1 DEC 2019</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Pg-1-DEC-2019.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":378,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Pg-2-DEC-2019.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Pg-2-DEC-2019.pdf">Pg 2 DEC 2019</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Pg-2-DEC-2019.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":379,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Calendar-DEC-2019.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Calendar-DEC-2019.pdf">Calendar DEC 2019</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Calendar-DEC-2019.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>380</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2019-12-04 20:09:14]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2019-12-04 20:09:14]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[december-2019]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>January 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/january-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Dec 2019 19:27:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=395</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"align":"center"} -->
<h3 style="text-align:center"><strong>From Day to Day</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Sing to the Lord, all the earth! Tell of His salvation from day to day.&nbsp;&nbsp;   1 Chronicles 16:23</em></strong><br></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Do you sing to the Lord where you are planted in your everyday life?&nbsp; Are you preparing well for the future by being faithful in the work of today?&nbsp; The right here, right now?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Upwards of half of Americans make New Year Resolutions during the month of January.&nbsp; I am among them; perhaps, you are as well?&nbsp; While such resolutions have some foundation in religion, today it seems most simply want to improve an area of life, grow in faith, pour more deeply into relationships, and the like.&nbsp; We resolve to do better in the new year. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Not surprisingly, researchers
report that 88% of such resolutions will fail by the end of February. Nearly all
my personal resolutions follow the pattern and have not been sustained.&nbsp; Several years ago, I resolved simply to sit
still and quietly for 10 minutes per day.&nbsp;
To contemplate, think, meditate, and to rest.&nbsp; How difficult could that possibly be?&nbsp; It turns out, very.&nbsp; I made it 4 days. 4 days!&nbsp; It seems resolving is easy – sustaining is
not.&nbsp; It takes work.&nbsp; The everyday kind of work.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A second scenario.&nbsp; Last evening, I spoke with several recent graduates of Southern Seminary.&nbsp; Both have advanced theological degrees and are aiming at lives of ministry.&nbsp; They are exactly the types of men and women that we in the church pray for in considering who we will one day hand the baton.&nbsp; They are gifted, affirm the calling upon their lives, and want to be employed mightily in
God’s work.&nbsp; They yearn for tomorrow and
searchingly seek “how to get there”.&nbsp;
Yet, they are stuck and tempted to miss the possibility of today.&nbsp;&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Lastly, I know a man who is the
son of a Pastor.&nbsp; As the son tells the story, his father was always about
imagining the day the church would be much larger, doing bigger things for the
Lord, maybe even personally going into overseas missions.&nbsp; And then my acquaintance recalls, "Never
once in all of my upbringing did Dad read us kids the Bible.&nbsp; Not
once.&nbsp; I am not kidding."&nbsp;&nbsp; This father missed the
possibility of his todays.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The learning of all three
scenarios is this - the enemy of today is oft the dreaming of tomorrow.&nbsp; While we desire doing big things for God, God
measures our readiness by the faithfulness of our doing the work He has
allocated to us this very day:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>His master said to him,
‘Well done, good and faithful servant.&nbsp;You have been faithful over a
little; I will set you over much. Enter into the joy of your master.’&nbsp;
Matthew 25:21</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I made resolutions for 2020.&nbsp; I want to succeed in them and be a little bit better because of it.&nbsp; This much is certain - if I should be among the 12% that will accomplish resolutions this year, it will be because I have been found faithful in the work of 365 days.&nbsp; Today is a gift and its work is enough (Matthew 6:34).  Such truth permeates New Year resolutions, calls to ministry, and a father’s priority of the home too.&nbsp;  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Grace, Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":398,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Front-page-JAN-2020.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Front-page-JAN-2020.pdf">Front page JAN 2020</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Front-page-JAN-2020.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":409,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Back-page-JAN-2020-1.pdf"} -->

<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":410,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Calendar-JAN-2020-1.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Calendar-JAN-2020-1.pdf">Calendar JAN 2020</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/Calendar-JAN-2020-1.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_author_IP><![CDATA[207.180.234.123]]></wp:comment_author_IP>

			<wp:comment_id>3</wp:comment_id>

					</item>
					<item>
		<title>February 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/february-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 25 Feb 2020 11:19:13 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=442</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p style="text-align:center" class="has-medium-font-size"><strong>As Fits the Occasion</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em>Let no corrupting talk come out of your mouths, but only such as is good for building up, as fits the occasion, that it may give grace to those who hear.  Ephesians 4:29</em></strong><br></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As we journey through the Epistle of Ephesians, we have often met “challenges” to the way that we are exhorted to speak to one another in God’s community.  Against the backdrop of church unity, we are warned in the Scriptures to be slow to speak, to guard our mouths, to put away foolish talk and crude joking, to bridle our tongues, and to give watch over our lips, the door to our mouths.  It seems that one of the most significant barriers to unity among God’s people is the hurt caused by our communications with one another.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sociologist reveal in increasing wariness
the “sharpness” of our society’s dialog with one another in our day.&nbsp; In a generation fueled by sound clips and
140-character tweets, the harshness of communication has accelerated; not
surprisingly, so has the hurt.&nbsp; The tide
of our cultural river sweeps many in its torrent.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Paul’s words, and the eternal
message of the Bible, remain of paramount importance today.&nbsp; Christians are not immune from the temptation
to speak our mind, and sadly, often in situations wholly out of turn and
without proper contextualization.&nbsp; In
military terms, such “friendly-fire” lobs hurtful consequences upon God’s
people and our demonstration of His glory among the peoples.&nbsp; We must be on guard; we must be faithful to
the Word.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There is a phrase in v29 that I beg
of your attention.&nbsp; That phrase, “as fits
the occasion” offers guidance for the Believer in how, and significantly when,
to navigate between speaking the truth in love on one occasion and holding our
tongue in another.&nbsp; The Christian is told
to demonstrate godly discernment in determining not only the timing of
conversation, but also the manner.&nbsp; As
fits.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Many pursue misplaced liberty, under
the guise of Christian conviction and duty, to speak their mind in all times
and in all places.&nbsp; Such unbridled tongues
rarely edify fellow brothers or sisters.&nbsp;
Often such self-serving talk builds friction between those who are
called to be bright lights to a watching world.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Paul provides guide rails for
those wishing to speak well.&nbsp; First, is
our speaking of a holy and sanctifying nature?&nbsp;
Some language offers nothing other than hurt, causing corruption that
impedes the efficient working of the Body. That kind of talk is rightly
admonished by the Apostle.&nbsp; Secondly,
will my “truth in love” moment build up my brother, and by extension, His
church?&nbsp; We usually know the answer and
it is our duty to obey His Spirit’s leading in such occasions.&nbsp; Lastly, the Apostle urges, do our words show
grace, and rightly point others to His grace, His atonement, His salvation?&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Unity hangs in the messy divide between speaking Grace and Truth.  Such tension is best labeled LOVE among the faithful.   Lord, give us strength to go after such a love!<strong><br> </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":443,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Front-page-FEB-2020.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Front-page-FEB-2020.pdf">Front page FEB 2020</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Front-page-FEB-2020.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":444,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Back-page-FEB-2020.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Back-page-FEB-2020.pdf">Back page FEB 2020</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Back-page-FEB-2020.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":445,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Calendar-FEB-2020.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Calendar-FEB-2020.pdf">Calendar FEB 2020</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Calendar-FEB-2020.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2020-02-25 11:19:13]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>March 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/march-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Mar 2020 15:02:09 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=450</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p style="text-align:center" class="has-medium-font-size"><strong>Be Kind To One Another</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p style="text-align:left" class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em>Be kind to one another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, as God in Christ forgave you.&nbsp; Ephesians 4:32</em></strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Friendship has been forefront of my mind this week.&nbsp; We unexpectedly lost a sister in Christ this week who frequented our sanctuary.&nbsp; As the family processed through the reality of the logistics before them, a comment from the grieving son shook my soul.&nbsp; After expressing unsureness about a service, “She didn’t have many friends”. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Researchers report the ever-present reality of loneliness in our culture.&nbsp; While there is much debate regarding its primary cause, there is little doubt that it results in disarray and pain within our communities, churches, and personal lives too.&nbsp; I speak with many who attest to living these truths.&nbsp; Many feel similarly even within the Church House of God.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How do you compare with the
findings? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Women typically have 2-3 friends.</li><li>Men have perhaps 1 friend.  Maybe.</li><li>Most friendships originate in the workplace, via other friends, or in the neighborhood.</li><li>Friendships are chosen based upon similarities; Opposites do not attract.</li><li>Evangelicals have few friends unlike themselves. </li><li>Church is often not where God’s children find their closest friends.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>While we cannot know for sure whether our sister truly felt lonely, or had many friends or few, we can be certain that every single member, and guest too, of Audubon are precious in the eyes of Jesus and they must be so with us as well.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em>For God so loved the world, that He gave His only Son, that whoever believes in Him should not perish, but have everlasting life.   John 3:16</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What amazing love!   While it may be difficult to foster solutions for loneliness in the community, we can start this very week by being friends, genuine friends, with one another in His House.  We can find ways to build that next relationship with someone sitting in our vicinity, singing to the same Lord, needing a warm hug and encouragement. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Together, we learned great spiritual truths as we worked our way through Ephesians 4.  We’ve learned of gifts given to the Church, a call to unity, a call to growth and togetherness, exhortations to throw off that Old Self and put on the New.  Remarkable and challenging.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Yet, how does the Apostle Paul conclude this beautiful section of Scripture?&nbsp; “Be kind to one another”.&nbsp; When all else is said, we are told to be kind to one another.&nbsp; Some might say, to be good friends.&nbsp; This is the picture that our culture desperately needs to see from the Church.&nbsp; May it be so for those that are watching.&nbsp; And may it be so for those of us sitting in our pews too.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Let’s be friends! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":451,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Front-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Front-Page.pdf">Front Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Front-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":452,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Back-page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Back-page.pdf">Back page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Back-page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":453,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Calendar.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Calendar.pdf">Calendar</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Calendar.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>April 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/april-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 29 Mar 2020 12:34:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=472</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p style="text-align:center" class="has-medium-font-size"><strong>Life Comes at You Fast</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em>I hope to see you soon, and we will talk face to face.&nbsp; 3 John 14</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I
watch very little TV, but one of my favorite commercial series of all-time was
titled, “Life Comes at You Fast” by Nationwide.&nbsp;
Perhaps you remember them?&nbsp; There
were all kinds of scenarios, each laughable because they were so real, and they
reminded us that we can be on a planned and purposeful course one moment, and
then snap, just like that, life comes at us fast.&nbsp; And with it and it’s insistent moment,
everything changes.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As I
write, just a few quick hours ago, I slowly turned a facet in our basement in
the counterclockwise direction.&nbsp; I turned
it slow and steady and with a purposeful commitment, just how the Youtube video
showed.&nbsp; It was only one small faucet,
the circular ones that I had turned countless times before.&nbsp; You know the ones; you’ve turned them
too.&nbsp; And then everything changed in our
home’s plumbing.&nbsp; Life came at me fast.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sunday
evening lesson #1 – Becoming a plumber via Youtube tutorial is not the best
approach.&nbsp; No matter how many
“likes”.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But I
turned it none the less.&nbsp; Determinedly.&nbsp; With a smile.&nbsp;
I was so sure.&nbsp; And now, it is
Sunday evening and our home is without water and we are using buckets filled
outside to flush our toilets.&nbsp; The family
won’t look at me without smiling, trying to make it okay.&nbsp; They are making strange jokes to lighten the
tension.&nbsp; I’ve commanded them to stop.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sunday
evening lesson #2 – When you need a plumber, you really need a plumber (and
Sunday evening is not the ideal time to find one).&nbsp; Now I live with the consequences of a
momentary decision.&nbsp; And the ones I love
live with the consequences too. <strong><em></em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em>If you do
right, won't you be accepted? But if you do not do right, sin is crouching at
the door. Its desire is for you, but you must master it.&nbsp; Genesis 4:7</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>While Monday’s schedule has now changed due to my plumbing
project, that is not my utmost concern tonight.&nbsp;
In recent weeks I have spoken with friends that lives changed in a
moment.&nbsp; Sin was crouching at their door,
and now they, and the ones they love too, live in its aftermath.&nbsp; <strong><em></em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have walked this same experience.&nbsp; I have walked with the reality of “broken
bones,” as the Psalmist refers, bones broken by sin.&nbsp; I inherited the same gene.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em>So she took
some of its fruit and ate it; she also gave some to her husband, who was with
her, and he ate it.&nbsp; Genesis 3:6</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Paul reminds me truthfully, that in a moment, life came at me
fast; faster than I could handle.&nbsp; And I
bit down on the apple.<strong><em></em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em>For all have
sinned&nbsp;and fall short of the&nbsp;glory of God.&nbsp; Romans 3:23</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It
is later Sunday evening now and the family is learning dishes will remain
dirty, baths will not occur, and we are “roughing it” as we make plans to watch
a Redbox.&nbsp; My hope in myself to resolve
our water issue has vanished.&nbsp; My mistake
has created real consequences for me.&nbsp; My
mistake has created real consequences for my family, too.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sunday
evening lesson #3 – Plumbers are heroes and can make wrongs, right again on
Monday (at least I hope so).&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sin
isn’t so easily resolved.&nbsp; Its
consequences linger.&nbsp; Sin memories tap
our shoulders often and remind us of our humanness.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Restore the
joy of your salvation to me, and sustain me by giving me a willing spirit.&nbsp; Psalm 51:12</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Brothers
and sisters that I love, may I remind you (and me) this evening, that, despite
our sin, and more precisely because of it, we share a redeemer who has paid the
price at Calvary.&nbsp; With His very
life.&nbsp; For you, and for me.&nbsp; Life came at us fast.&nbsp; We bit down.&nbsp;
And He paid the price and paid it in full.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When
I stop and ponder such truth from Scripture, it is almost too much to
consider.&nbsp; Understanding escapes me.&nbsp; This evening, I am simply in awe of Him,
remembering again, when I bit down on the apple, He was right there waiting for
me.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As
we enter the Easter season, let us remind one another of that hope we profess
as His church; a hope that has overwhelmed death and the consequences of sin.&nbsp; When life came at us fast.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Oh Lord,
restore to me the joy of your salvation!</em></strong>&nbsp; Lord, remind me, too, that I am
called; I am beloved, and I am kept by and for my Savior Jesus Christ.&nbsp; Forever and ever.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>All glory to the King of Kings,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":475,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Front-Page-1.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Front-Page-1.pdf">Front Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Front-Page-1.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":476,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Back-page-1.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Back-page-1.pdf">Back page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Back-page-1.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":477,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Calendar-1.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Calendar-1.pdf">Calendar</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Calendar-1.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
										<category domain="category" nicename="uncategorized"><![CDATA[Uncategorized]]></category>
						</item>

					<item>
		<title>The Aftermath</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?post_type=sermons&#038;p=404</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?post_type=sermons&#038;p=404</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h5>TEXT Matthew 2</h5>
[audio mp3="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Ephesians-2-1-7.mp3"][/audio]
<h5 style="text-align: center;">11.3.2019 by Pastor Dan Hatfield</h5>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>404</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2019-12-30 19:43:49]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[0000-00-00 00:00:00]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[draft]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[sermons]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>

		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>May 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/may-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 29 Apr 2020 23:56:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=483</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"very-dark-gray","fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-medium-font-size has-very-dark-gray-color"><strong>Our God is in the heavens;
He does all that He pleases.&nbsp; Psalm 115:3</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I wrote the Newsletter for April some five
weeks ago and titled it, “Life Comes at You Fast”.&nbsp; My, oh, my; I had no idea.&nbsp; In the span of time since I wrote those
words, most everything I once considered normal has been turned topsy turvy by
a virus named Corona.&nbsp; Phrases like
“Social Distancing” have exploded forth in my vernacular and are universally
understood among the nations.&nbsp; I struggle
to regain my footing each day, wondering when, and if, things might return to
my familiar and comfortable routine.&nbsp;
Perhaps, you understand?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Increasingly, I hear some ponder whether God
is correcting His people in this moment, whether this is a “getting of our
attention.”&nbsp; Certainly, such voices find
home within the Scriptures, for in times throughout history, God utilized similar
pandemic-like moments to shake His people.&nbsp;
Yet, concerning this time, how are we to truly know?&nbsp; And a better question, should knowing even
matter to us?&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>While we strain to understand our
circumstances, we can be sure of several Biblical truths.&nbsp; We can know them with clairvoyant certainty.&nbsp; First, <strong>Our God is in the heavens; He does
all that He pleases (Psalm 115:3).&nbsp; </strong>Nothing
concerning the Corona virus catches God the Father off-guard.&nbsp; None of it is without reason, even if we do
not understand.&nbsp; Maybe we shall understand
in time, perhaps not.&nbsp; It does not
matter. Our obedience to God, and our full trust in Him, must be untethered to
our understanding.&nbsp; Not just in this
moment, but always.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If we are not attentive, we may find ourselves begrudging the beauty of our days, questioning the Sovereignty of our Creator, wondering if everything is being worked together for our good, for we called according to His purpose (Romans 8:28).&nbsp; Thinking in these ways not only proves unhelpful in walking joyfully day by day, such places us squarely in intellectual and emotional opposition to the very character of God.&nbsp; We must remain vigilant and guard against our fallen humanness in our pondering.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If questioning God and His sovereignty is so very off-track, what then should we do during this time of reflection?&nbsp; John records in the Book of Revelation Jesus’ continual observation of, and guiding of, and correction of too, the churches prominent during John’s writing.&nbsp; I have been drawn recently to Revelation Chapter 2, where Jesus speaks to the angel of the church at Ephesus. Among other things, Jesus confronts the angel; they have abandoned their first love, they have been busy and left that love.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Leaving here rightly announces a conscience choice to go after something different, and if I may, a lusting after imitation. Some imitations can indeed appear incredibly good, enticing, so dividing of our attention and love.&nbsp; The church at Ephesus did many good and wonderful things. Yet, they veered from their first love, a love that was pure and life-giving, a genuine love for Christ and one another.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Churches across America do wonderful things
too. Right alongside the church at Ephesus, many do amazing work within their
communities, toil to the utmost, renounce evil, and faithfully test teachings
against the Word of God.&nbsp; &nbsp;Yet, do they love Jesus as they did at first?&nbsp; Even more than the good works and the
busyness and the community prominence and recognition?&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It is easy for me us to stare and evaluate
others and their ministries – to judge others as the Bible rightly
alleges.&nbsp; Again, Jesus’ words to the
church at Ephesus provide insight and leave no ambiguity; the words stop me.
Jesus speaks directly to the angel of Ephesus, and to us by extension, and ask
us to keep our nose in the Book and our eyes upon our business alone.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Which has me back to the beginning.  What exactly is God up with COVID-19?  Not globally or even within other church houses, but within A Church in the Park?  As I typed the calendar for this month, I was struck by how simple, and focused, our church has become in this moment.  Is it possible that our foundations have been shaken to refocus us, and delight more, in our first love<em>?  </em>I cannot know.  But this I do; we are called upon in Scripture to precisely do that. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>God will show His works, and His faithful church will be changed.  Corona has created a beauty in our worship, a togetherness in our voices, a longing to be face to face, that I am unsure would have occurred without our slowing down, without this Corona moment.&nbsp; And for that, I live today with wondrous thanksgiving.   I am blessed.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>All glory to the King of Kings.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":488,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/front-page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/front-page.pdf">front page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/front-page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":489,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/back-page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/back-page.pdf">back page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/back-page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":490,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/calendar.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/calendar.pdf">calendar</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/calendar.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>483</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2020-04-29 23:56:43]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2020-04-29 23:56:43]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[may-2020]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>June 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/june-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 02 Jun 2020 19:50:55 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=499</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Not to us, O&nbsp;Lord, not to us, but to your name be the glory, for the sake
of your steadfast love and your faithfulness!&nbsp; Psalm 115:1</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>These COVID days have created an appetite for
worship that seems wholly unlike other “growth” seasons of my life.&nbsp; I marvel that amid this topsy-turvy season, when
my footing is off-balance and shifted, when face-face relationship moments are scarce,
exactly why it is that I feel closer to God and closer to His chosen?&nbsp; Increasingly, it seems as if I am climbing
toward a spiritual summit with panoramic vistas instead of traversing towards
the valley I expected.&nbsp; None of this
makes any sense to me in midst of a global pandemic. Yet, God reminds me: <strong>My
thoughts are not your thoughts, neither are your ways my ways, declares
the&nbsp;Lord. </strong>&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have spoken to many of you in recent weeks
and told of my belief that our congregation is growing stronger <strong>in the unity
of the faith and of the knowledge of the Son of God</strong>, even during these days
that none of anticipated, none of us chose.&nbsp;
I have been encouraged by your testimonies of being drawn closer to Him
in prayer and study, your prayer on Saturday mornings, your proclamations of
truth on Sunday mornings, and our spoken longing to be together again.&nbsp; We follow in the footsteps of our forefathers
and foremothers who were strengthened by God, for God, during past times of unexpected
challenge and sharpening, refining as the Bible speaks.&nbsp; The Scriptures are filled with such accounts.<strong> &nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I recall one of my favorites that comes from
Zechariah 13:8, “And I will put this third into the fire, and refine them as one refines silver, and test them as
gold is tested. <strong>They will call upon my name, and I will answer them. I
will say, ‘They are my people’; and they will say, ‘The&nbsp;Lord&nbsp;is my God.’ </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What a promise of Scripture.&nbsp; As one of your pastors, I pray that Dan and I
might lead a people of which it may be said, <strong>They will call upon my name,
and I will answer them. &nbsp;I will say,
‘They are my people’; and they will say, ‘The&nbsp;Lord&nbsp;is my God.’&nbsp;
</strong>There is no higher vision for us.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Yet, to gain the fuller picture of this promise,
and how transformative it is for the people of God, we look to the context of
Zechariah 12 and 13.&nbsp; Zechariah 12 ends
with Israel’s return to the Lord through
the once rejected and murdered, but now embraced, Messiah.&nbsp; Flowing from their embrace of the Messiah,
Christ Jesus, they would enjoy an ever-flowing fountain of cleansing for sin
and uncleanness. &nbsp;As some have commented,
this is not simply a fountain opened, but a fountain that remains open for us,
bubbling forth for all time sake for His people. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have been refreshed in my faith during these days with a realization that this too is my position before a Holy God.  The fountain bubbles forth for me, and you, in June 2020.  Oh, how I long to be with you soon, singing in one accord, words written by William Cowper in 1772, <em><strong>“There is a fountain filled with blood drawn from Emmanuel’s veins; and sinners plunged beneath that flood lose all their guilty stains.”</strong>   </em>Jesus’ fountain shall never run dry.  And we are cleansed!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Not to us, O Lord, not to us, but to your name be the glory</strong>.   </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":500,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Front-page-2020-JUNE.pdf"} -->

<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>499</wp:post_id>

		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[june-2020]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>July 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/doing-good/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 02 Jul 2020 18:25:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=517</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>DOING GOOD</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>And let us not grow weary of doing good,
for in due season we will reap, if we do not give up.&nbsp; Galatians 6:9</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Christians have been challenged since the
earliest days of the church to “do good”.&nbsp;
While we may be prone to believe that our time is unlike any other in
history, the truth is that there is nothing new under the Sun.&nbsp; We, like those before us, are called to take
the love of Christ outward into our community and, with His blessing, to the
nations. We are told to not grow weary of doing good, to not give up.&nbsp; Such is a timely reminder in the midst of all
we see and feel in these days, tensions that purpose to divide, not only
neighbors, but brothers and sisters of the faith as well.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I spoke with a dear friend this week who
sought counsel on how he could be more effective on social media “for the
Lord”, in communicating his views amid the tensions of today.&nbsp; I asked him, “Why would you do that?”&nbsp; I counseled him to stop. &nbsp;Communicating one’s feelings via social media
is far from the Biblical teachings of doing good.&nbsp; Post if you must, beloved, but do not give up
doing good.&nbsp; Doing good involves loving
our neighbor as ourselves in ways that are tangible and real, eye-catching to
others amid a culture of much talking.&nbsp; We
cannot give up.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As I write this evening, we remain in a
global pandemic, we experience racial tensions beyond those experienced in a
generation, unemployment has reached Great Depression levels, hatred spews
forth from our politics, and local churches seem rocked back upon their heels,
still grappling with the effects of COVID-19 restrictions. I wonder how we, beloved Audubon, are doing good in these
days?&nbsp; Are we resolutely doing good for our
neighbors?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I am a pastor in a local church.&nbsp; I love the local church.&nbsp; I love all that it stands for, the hope that
God has placed in it for making His great name known among the nations, and the
picture of Christ’ Bride that it represents.&nbsp;
I love that the local church is God’s plan for humanity through its
presentation of the gospel and its doing good, and that there is not a backup
plan. &nbsp;I love that it is in, and through,
the local church that theology gets practiced, words become actions, and
knowledge becomes love; if we do not grow weary, if we do not give up.&nbsp;                                                   </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"id":524,"width":390,"height":288} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image is-resized"><img src="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/oiklj-1.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-524" width="390" height="288"/></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Many will recognize the Dandelion flower and wonder just how many seeds such a thing can cast among a neatly landscaped yard?  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have this image in my
mind, really a prayer on my heart, that Audubon would be like the Dandelion
flower blown on by a child.&nbsp; Taking the
promptings of the Spirit, may we be blown outward from Audubon, doing good wherever
the Spirit blows us, just like the wind and Dandelion seeds.&nbsp; I am convinced that our love would be
demonstrable, our impact would be great, and many would be drawn to Christ; a
harvest to reap in due season.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This is my prayer.  I pray it may be so this very day.  <strong>Not to us, O Lord, not to us, but to your name be the glory</strong>.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":529,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Front-Page-July-2020.pdf"} -->

							</item>
					<item>
		<title>August 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/august-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 31 Jul 2020 13:34:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=549</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>A DIVIDED HEART</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>And Elijah came near to all the people and said, “How
long&nbsp;will you go limping between two different opinions?&nbsp;If the&nbsp;Lord&nbsp;is God, follow Him; but if
Baal, then follow him.” And the people did not answer him a word.&nbsp; &nbsp;1
Kings 18:21</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In one of the great
historical accounts of the O.T., Elijah confronts King Ahab for leading God’s
people astray from Yahweh. The prophet challenges Ahab’s prophets of the idol
Baal to a winner-take-all showdown, Elijah standing alone against 450 Baal
prophets.&nbsp; Elijah suggests each side
sacrifice a bull and await fire upon their respective altar. The Baal prophets
take the bull that is given, and prepare it, and call upon the name of Baal
from morning to noon, “O Baal, answer us!”&nbsp;
Approaching noon, Elijah taunts, “Cry aloud, for he is a god. Either he
is musing, or he is relieving himself, or he is a journey, or perhaps he is
asleep and must be awakened.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The confrontation is, of
course, not fair.&nbsp; One side represents
what is false; Elijah stands with the true and living God.&nbsp; The people watch.&nbsp; Elijah calls upon God, “Answer me, O Lord, answer me, that this people may
know that you, O Lord, are God,
and that you have turned their hearts back.”&nbsp;
On cue, the fire falls from Heaven and consumes the offering.&nbsp; The people fall on their faces and turn back,
and choose the Lord.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have occasionally imagined
this scene since first hearing of it as a child. The confrontation demonstrates
the power of God, so that the people are reproved for their vacillation and
idolatry, and challenged to choose for the Lord.
They must choose fully for the Lord.&nbsp; Elijah insightfully asks, “How long will you
go limping between the two different opinions?”&nbsp;
Such a question lands squarely in our laps as well.&nbsp; Can we expect to worship God in spirit and in
truth while embracing different opinions?&nbsp;
We cannot.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We live in what theologians declare
the “Already, Not Yet” time of human history.&nbsp;
A great battle rages,&nbsp; between that
which is false and that which is true.&nbsp; A
battle between that which seeks to deceive, stealing our hearts, and that which
offers truth and an unabashed demand for worship and obedience from the
created.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>These are matters of
paramount importance that have practical impact upon the way we live our days.&nbsp; Who shall we worship, and will we do so fully?&nbsp; The tempter still tempts, with one
overarching goal – to have us take our eyes off our Lord and Savior Jesus
Christ, dividing our attention.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>John Newton, the great
Anglican preacher and abolitionisht, once wrote “I find no Scriptural evidence
that we serve the Lord at all, any farther than we find a habitual desire and
aim to serve Him wholly.&nbsp; He is gracious
to our imperfections and weakness; yet he requires all the heart, and will not
be served by halves, nor accept what is performed by a divided heart.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In August, Pastor Dan will preach through the culmination text of Ephesians, “The Armor of God”.  The word armor rightly brings forth images in our minds of battle.  One doesn’t accidently wear armor; it is worn on purpose, anticipating action, trusting it will serve the wearer well.  It protects, aiming to deflect or absorb impacts thrown from one’s enemy with the intention of hurt or fatality.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Beloved, we do not walk in
peacetime.&nbsp; The enemy is crafty and
intends to deceive us into a divided worship; Ephesians 6:10-20 shall steady us
and prepare us for his manuevers and battletime conditions.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Let us rally under the
preaching of God’s Word this month, keeping alert with all perseverance, so
that we may be able to stand against&nbsp;the schemes of our enemy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Following Him,</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Pastor Jeff</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":550,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Newsletter-2020-August-Front-page-2020.pdf"} -->

<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>

							</item>
					<item>
		<title>September 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/september-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 02 Sep 2020 13:01:38 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=569</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Hiding from God’s Presence</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em><strong>And they heard the sound of the LORD God walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and the man and his wife hid themselves from the presence of the LORD God among the trees of the garden.  Genesis 3:8</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Christians agree that the
Bible speaks great truth, a truth that is unwavering from the earliest of
written accounts.&nbsp; We love how in our
study of Ephesians the truth of God’s Word tells us that we are free, God has
done the work already in His Son Jesus Christ, and while there is diversity in
the Body, oneness is a higher call, oneness only possible in and through Him.&nbsp; Such truths are what we long for as created
beings.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But, how shall we respond to
truth when it hits a bit closer to home?&nbsp;
When truth arrives with an intent to correct or perhaps urge us higher
in our spiritual disciplines and pursuit of Him?&nbsp; How shall we respond to God’s Word when it illuminates
our tendency towards sin, and its natural impulse to hide from a God that loves
us?&nbsp; Do we love it just as much when the
Bible speaks these truths? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Early in the Biblical
account we find&nbsp; Adam and Eve hiding from
God, their God with whom moments earlier they enjoyed perfect and harmonious
relationship.&nbsp; Let that sink in to your
mind.&nbsp; Hiding.&nbsp; From God.&nbsp;
One moment walking with God, the next moment hiding from Him.&nbsp; On the face it seems preposterous.&nbsp; Silly.&nbsp;
Fool hearted.&nbsp; Something a child
might try.&nbsp; Hiding from God?&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We understand Adam and Eve.  Immediately, we feel their need to hide.  God has placed understanding within each of us to intuitively know that His holiness, and our inability to be holy, are in conflict.  How can a God that is perfect accept the worship of beings that are not?  This circular logic has stretched the ruminations of thinkers for millenniums, around and around they go. Do you believe that we are immune from such faith crises? Think again.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Adam and Eve demonstrate how
quickly we place our inadequacies on the line in our relationship with
God.&nbsp; Sin fractures relationship with God,
casting feelings of unworthiness upon ourselves.&nbsp; Hiding from God happens lest we are displined
and on-guard and fight it with the truth of God’s Word. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The psalmist writes in <em><strong>Psalm 57:1, Be merciful to me, O God, be merciful to me.</strong></em><strong> </strong> While our tendency may be to play proverbial peek a boo with God, David reminds himself, and us too, of the opposite truth.  Our God is merciful and we need not hide.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>May I remind you that our God is
for us!&nbsp; He gave us His very own begotten
Son to save us from our rightful condemnation and to bring freedom.&nbsp; Will we live in light of the Cross and such a
gift?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Beloved, His mercy is great!&nbsp; His is a tender mercy, gentle, loving,
healing the broken hearted.&nbsp; It is a
great mercy.&nbsp; There is nothing little
with God.&nbsp; His mercy is so great that it
forgives great sins to great sinners, after great lengths of time and fallenness,
and then gives great favors and great privileges and great joys.&nbsp; It is a rich mercy.&nbsp; There is no single mercy, it is an abounding
mercy.&nbsp; Generations have received it, yet
it is far from being exhausted.&nbsp; It is
full and available and refreshing for those that drink it up.&nbsp; And maybe the best of all, it is an unfailing
mercy.&nbsp; When I fall down, when I run and
hide, His mercy does not.&nbsp; He patiently waits
for me to seek Him with my whole heart.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em><strong>Be merciful to me, O God, be merciful to me.</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Aren’t you so very thankful?&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Peace to you,  Pastor Jeff<br></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":570,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Newsletter-2020-September-Front-page.pdf"} -->

<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>

		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>October 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/october-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Sep 2020 15:59:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=587</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2> <strong>The Stampede for Normalcy </strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>And after you have suffered a little while, the God of all grace, who has called you to His eternal glory in Christ, will Himself restore, confirm, strengthen, and establish you.  1 PETER 5:10 </em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Suffering and the Christian life surely go hand in hand. Such was not explained to me as part of the invitation I accepted so many decades ago, but today, at the age of fifty-four, I can personally attest that it is so for me.  I am not alone. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At first blush, suffering and trial seem at odds with the faith we profess. In recent weeks, I have spoken to brothers and sisters in Christ, some in our church family, who are suffering and walking through the dry wilderness. Some are suffering through the loss of a loved one, or while caring for aged parents, others marital crises, employment loss, diagnosis of cancer, loneliness, fear of singleness, COVID weariness, health crises of various natures, acne, and the sufferings we see ongoing in our cherished Louisville. Hurt and suffering are visible in every direction; each and every situation is real and present and painful. How are we to rationalize such suffering juxtaposed against the love of Christ? </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The truth is that the Bible not only says that suffering and trial are possible for the Believer, the Bible promises it shall be so for each and every one of us. Yet, God remains the God of all grace. While our sufferings may differ, while some trials may appear frequent with waves higher than we can fathom, we can be certain that others face their own struggles. Such perspective undergirds suffering well; my experiences while unique are not all that unusual among fellow Believers. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We can also be confident that others care for us as well. One of the greatest gifts that comes from the fellowship is that we are not alone in suffering – we suffer together. If one member suffers, all suffer together (1 COR 12:26a) In our church, we suffer together, carrying burdens among many shoulders and committed knees bent in prayer. The ability of the church to be together in these ways surely depends upon the courage and vulnerability and openness of him who suffers. To me, such seems a hallmark of our church and the love we carry for one another and is a vibrant testimony to those who watch. This is how it should be among those faithful in Christ Jesus. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Yet, there is another aspect of suffering and trial that requires attention. In many conversations, almost on cue, the words “I can’t wait to get back to normal” are spoken. If you listen for them when speaking to others concerning trial, you will hear them too –the stampede for normalcy. Few mean anything contrary with such utterances; neither do I. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Yet, the spoken words do tell. Such belies a contentment in the moment God has ordained for us. Our desires attest to a soul’s longing for equilibrium, no matter the will of God. We aggressively seek the just right state of “normal”, where the tensions and stresses are low, and our angst and struggles are few. A French poet named Pierre Reverdy in the early 1900s penned, “The point in life is to find equilibrium in what is inherently unstable.” Not much has changed; I feel the emotional pull of his words. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In my readings of Scripture equilibrium appears contrary to the pathways God most frequently journeys His children. I do not find names listed in Hebrews 11 that avoided trial and suffering. I do not find the Prophets or Apostles commending God’s chosen in the day to hurry past it all, to seek equilibrium and live best lives in the moment. Instead, my mind and soul feast on words like after you have suffered a little while, and many are the afflictions of the righteous, and all who live a godly life will be persecuted, and this momentary affliction is preparing us, and yes too – praise God, all things work together for our good. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Audubon family, it is natural and easy to want to wish past our sufferings, to get to the other side and have everything back to normal. Suffering is uncomfortable, often confusing, and knocks us off balance in our relationship with God. Let us take solace and confidence from a frequent sufferer. In the words of the Apostle Peter, written for you and for me, <strong><em>After you have suffered a little while, the God of all grace, who has called you to His eternal glory in Christ, will Himself restore, confirm, strengthen, and establish you.</em></strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Peace to you,  Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":588,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Newsletter-2020-October-Front-page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Newsletter-2020-October-Front-page.pdf">Newsletter 2020 October Front page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Newsletter-2020-October-Front-page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":589,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Newsletter-2020-Oct-Back-page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Newsletter-2020-Oct-Back-page.pdf">Newsletter 2020 Oct Back page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Newsletter-2020-Oct-Back-page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":590,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Calendar-2020-October.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Calendar-2020-October.pdf">Calendar 2020 October</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Calendar-2020-October.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>587</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2020-09-30 15:59:04]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2020-09-30 15:59:04]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
