							</item>
					<item>
		<title>November 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/november-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Nov 2020 02:16:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=608</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p class="has-medium-font-size"><strong>A Little Strength Conditioning</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><em>And do not be grieved, for the joy of the&nbsp;Lord&nbsp;is your strength.&nbsp;
Nehemiah 8:10b</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As I write, AmyJo and I are in deliberations about
what to give our daughter Abby for her upcoming birthday.&nbsp; We have six children that we love and
cherish; birthdays come around often. Yet, twenty-one is special and we
endeavor to make it a “really good one”.&nbsp;
Our considerations are into their 3<sup>rd</sup> hour and it feels like
there may yet be a while to go.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Through the years we have executed on many
ideas.&nbsp; Some were huge hits; some were
singles; some were, frankly, swings and misses.&nbsp;
We give things less and less.&nbsp; Currently,
our preference is to gift experiences that linger in the heart and mind long
after one’s birthday.&nbsp; We especially like
to focus on relationship building among our family members or perhaps learning
experiences that can be taken forward.&nbsp;
The possibilities are endless, and thus the dilemma; we enter our 4<sup>th</sup>
hour.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As we study the First Epistle of John, I
return often to the thought of strength.&nbsp;
John is writing to a people that have been weakened in their faith and
tossed by the culture.&nbsp; It seems to me
that they, and we, can use a good infusion of strength.&nbsp;&nbsp; How can we as Christians be stronger amid
the decay of our society?&nbsp; How can we be
stronger when trials come our way?&nbsp; How
can we be stronger when temptation comes calling and doubts arise?&nbsp;&nbsp; How can we be stronger when we wonder about
His plans for our lives? &nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The Bible has much to say about strength,
specifically, where and how we are to seek it:&nbsp;
</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"very-dark-gray"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-very-dark-gray-color"><em>I&nbsp;am your God; I will strengthen you;
I will help you, I will uphold you (Is. 41:10); The&nbsp;Lord&nbsp;is my strength and my song
(Ex. 15:2); Be strong in the Lord
(Ep. 6:10); My power is made perfect in weakness (1 Cor. 12:9); </em><em>He gives power</em><em> to the faint,
and to </em><em>h</em><em>im who has no
might </em><em>H</em><em>e increases strength</em><em> (Is. 40:29)</em><em>; </em><em>God, the Lord, is my strength</em><em>; </em><em>H</em><em>e makes my
feet like the deer's (Hab. 3:19)</em><em>.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Do you see it too?&nbsp; Page after page in Scripture affirms God –
His strength given to us; His strength through us; His strength in us.<em>&nbsp; My flesh
and my heart may fail, but God is the strength of my heart and my
portion forever (Ps 73:26).</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What
then shall our response be when we tend to pursue our own strength, think of
ourselves as either strong or weak as we journey through our days, fight our
own battles?&nbsp; The writer of Chronicles
puts it straightforward, <em>Seek the&nbsp;Lord&nbsp;and
His strength; seek His presence continually! (1 Chr. 16:11).&nbsp; </em>What if we committed to spending more time
seeking the Lord and His strength
and presence, and less time pondering our emotions and feelings and personal weaknesses?&nbsp; How might outcomes be different?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The Old Testament provides clarity.&nbsp; When God’s people went forward of their own
power, they were defeated time and time again.&nbsp;
When they advanced under the Lord’s
strength, the victory – some astounding – are recorded in the history of God’s
chosen people.&nbsp; Own power, defeat.&nbsp; God’s power, victory.&nbsp; Shall we think it different today?&nbsp; Beloved, we must go forward with His strength
and power!&nbsp; What a gift to the child of
God if we only allow it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Abby turns twenty-one is just a few
days.&nbsp; AmyJo and I consider the
possibility of strength and flexibility conditioning for her under the tutelage
of a coach, someone that can encourage and teach her, point her towards
readying herself for the years ahead, imparting confidence and belief.&nbsp; Such are goals that she has communicated to
our family and we stand with her in these worthy endeavors.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Spiritually, all children of God benefit from
strength conditioning as well.&nbsp; The Word
urges nothing short of commitment, preparation, work, and the steady
encouragement of others in conditioning ourselves well for “in the Lord”.&nbsp;
&nbsp;The times will surely come when
strength in the Lord is required
for each of us.&nbsp; Will we be ready?&nbsp; I pray that you may proclaim in that day, <em>God, the Lord, is my strength</em><em>.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Truth, Grace, and Peace to you, Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":609,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Newsletter-2020-November-Front-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Newsletter-2020-November-Front-Page.pdf">Newsletter 2020 November Front Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Newsletter-2020-November-Front-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":610,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Back-Page-2020-November.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Back-Page-2020-November.pdf">Back Page 2020 November</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Back-Page-2020-November.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":611,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Calendar-2020-November.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Calendar-2020-November.pdf">Calendar 2020 November</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Calendar-2020-November.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

							</item>
					<item>
		<title>December 2020</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/december-2020/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 01 Dec 2020 01:31:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=623</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"align":"center"} -->
<h3 style="text-align:center">Pleasant Places</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":4} -->
<h4> <br><em>Exodus 12:36, And the LORD had given the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians, so that they let them have what they asked. Thus they plundered the Egyptians.  </em></h4>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We are well into the holiday season, moving quickly from Thanksgiving and making our way toward Christmas. Even amid the reality of COVID and its impact upon our days, the season is undeniably underway with music in the air. I pray that your Thanksgiving was a good one, even if 2020 required a modified approach to usual traditions. We are a blessed people, <em><strong>we who are </strong></em><strong><em>called, beloved by the Father and kept for Jesus</em></strong>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Many of us studied the history of Israel in the Book of Exodus. We learned of God’s everlasting attributes and took note of how He works in the circumstances of His people to make His name great. I have particularly been drawn to how God provides for His people. Repeatedly, God provides for His people, in abundance, in miraculous ways, and the people worship His great name. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Tucked within later Chapter 12 of Exodus are a few short verses; it is easy to miss them. Through Moses, God has previously promised freedom, and plunder of the Egyptians on the Israelites’ way out of town. Now it happens, we read, <strong><em>The people of Israel had done as Moses told them, for they had asked the Egyptians for silver and gold jewelry and for clothing. And the LORD had given the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians, so that they let them have what they asked. Thus they plundered the Egyptians. </em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left"} -->
<p style="text-align:left">This may be one of the most incredible passages of Scripture. God, in His omnipotence, says through His servant Moses, “Ask them for their stuff, their best jewelry and Sunday ready clothes. Just ask these people that have enslaved you for 430 years, beaten rods across your backs in the hot summer sun. Ask them.” The Bible records the result, <strong><em>so they let them have what they asked. </em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I cannot think of a more demonstrable example of God’s provision. The Israelites ask their captors and receive. Shortly after, the Egyptians give chase once again. But for now, they open their treasure chests and give their best, seemingly, with joy. The Israelites depart Egypt with unleavened bread because they were thrust out; yet they leave with pockets full, bags stuffed, Egypt’s best. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We read no other details at this point in the narrative. It is much later in Exodus that we see the wondrous conclusion. Moses says to the people, <strong><em>This is the thing that the LORD has commanded. Take from among you a contribution to the LORD. Whoever is of a generous heart, let him bring the LORD's contribution: gold, silver, and bronze; blue and purple and scarlet yarns and fine twined linen. </em></strong>And a few short verses later, <strong><em>And they came, everyone whose heart stirred him, and everyone whose spirit moved him, and brought the LORD's contribution to be used for the tent of meeting, and for all its service, and for the holy garments. So they came, both men and women. All who were of a willing heart brought brooches and earrings and signet rings and armlets, all sorts of gold objects, every man dedicating an offering of gold to the LORD. </em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>The contributions poured in, Everyone who could make a contribution of silver or bronze brought it</em></strong>... God’s tabernacle would receive their very best, given to them by God, returned in worship. God didn’t take it from them, they offered it back as a freewill offering to the LORD. They offered in pureness of worship and thanksgiving for the wonders their lives enjoyed. The worship overwhelmed the artisans chosen to construct the tabernacle. Soon, <strong><em>The people were restrained from giving, for the material they had was sufficient to do all the work, and more.</em></strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This story gives me pause amid the blessings my life enjoys, especially in these anticipatory days leading to Christmas. <strong><em>The lines have fallen for me in pleasant places; indeed, I have a beautiful inheritance. </em></strong>As I remember the blessings given to me, probably no less wonderous than those given the Israelites, how shall I respond to God in worship? While we cannot contribute to God’s tabernacle, there are many ways that we can worship the LORD through our giving. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Many in our community hurt; many in our community go without, many in our community lack the Gospel that we cherish. Our church supports these worthy endeavors and more; you support these worthy endeavors and more. Your partnership in the Gospel is surely changing lives. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thank you, Audubon Baptist, we are members one of another. I pray that the greatest gift, the gift of Jesus Christ our Deliverer, may foster our worship of the Father, afresh this Christmas season. The lines have indeed fallen in pleasant places for us. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Peace to you, Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":630,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Front-Page.pdf"} -->

<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":631,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Back-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Back-Page.pdf">Back Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Back-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":632,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Calendar.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Calendar.pdf">Calendar</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Calendar.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":633,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/12/Poinsettias-order-form.pdf"} -->

<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>623</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2020-12-01 01:31:00]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[december-2020]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>January 2021</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/january-2021/</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 01 Jan 2021 16:37:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=645</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2><strong>Forgetting.  And Remembering.</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Isaiah 43:18-19a, </em></strong><strong><em>Forget</em></strong><strong><em>
the former things;</em></strong><strong><em> do not dwell on
the past.&nbsp; See, I am doing a new thing!&nbsp; Now it springs up; do you not perceive it.</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong><em>Isaiah 46:9, </em></strong><strong><em>Remember</em></strong><strong><em> the former things of old;
for I am God, and there is no other; I am God, and there is none like me.</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For many years I, like many Americans, placed unmerited significance upon January 1<sup>st</sup>.  This, of all the days, was the day that changes I desired for my life would be launched, perhaps even producing the ‘new and improved me’ in the year ahead.  Half of Louisville will make such a vow, about ten times the number deciding to make life changes at other times in the year.  Most years my results, meh. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My
resolutions have mostly reflected the general population; you will likely find
the following
familiar:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <strong><em>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</em></strong><strong><em>
 
 
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
 
 

 
</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"id":646,"align":"center","width":382,"height":445} -->
<div class="wp-block-image"><figure class="aligncenter is-resized"><img src="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Picture1.jpg" alt="" class="wp-image-646" width="382" height="445"/></figure></div>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have become a bit of a student psychologist
on the matter, reflecting year after year on my experiences.&nbsp; I find it rather perplexing that the most
important part of my life, spiritual knowledge of Him and incremental growth
into Jesus’ likeness, have received little of my committed attention.&nbsp; I remember several Bible reading plan
resolutions; I don’t recall others. Something has been amiss.&nbsp;&nbsp; I would like this year to be different.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>To be sure, there is O.T. support for
reflection and renewal of God’s people, requiring forward looking commitment
and resolution. The Day of Atonement was one such day in which the people were
called to reflect upon their wrongdoings and recommitment to doing better in
the year ahead.&nbsp; Year after year.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As I have begun to consider the year ahead, it
seems the Bible speaks with clairvoyant boundaries that shall serve us well in
our reflections and recommitments.&nbsp; On
the one hand, we are told to forget some things, things that generally hold us
back from forward progress in Him.&nbsp; <em>Forget the former things; do not dwell on the
past.</em>&nbsp; The prophet has in mind the memories, and
mistakes, the failure and sin and discouragement, of our pasts.&nbsp; If our attention rests upon these things, we
will not go forward.&nbsp; We misunderstand
and misapply the reality of grace. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On the other hand, we are instructed to remember
some things.&nbsp; Chief among these is that
we are no longer who we once were, that we are becoming new selves, and that
such is only possible because He is doing a new thing in us.&nbsp; We are told to remember these things, and put
action to them, and in doing so, we go forward.&nbsp;&nbsp; <em>For He is God, there is none other like Him.&nbsp; </em>He shall meet our efforts.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>What effort shall you make in the New Year to become
made more in the likeness of God in true righteousness and holiness?&nbsp; We mustn’t kid ourselves; the spiritual
disciplines requisite for growth in Him call us to action.&nbsp; What then shall you and I commit as the New
Year arrives? Will you commit to deeper personal study, or meeting with God’s
people for the study of His Word?&nbsp; Will you
reenergize your prayer life and join with others similarly committed?&nbsp; While January 1<sup>st</sup> may simply be
another gift from Him who showers steadfast love, it is surely as good as any
other day to decide, to commit, to reflect upon the beauty of our abundant
lives in Him.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I pray that we will make much of our days, beginning this January 1<sup>st</sup>.  They are, each and every one, a gift. Happy New Year Audubon.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>May God bless you,  Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":647,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Front-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Front-Page.pdf">Front Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Front-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":648,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Back-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Back-Page.pdf">Back Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Back-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":649,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Calendar.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Calendar.pdf">Calendar</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/Calendar.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>645</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2021-01-01 16:37:00]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2021-01-01 16:37:00]]></wp:post_date_gmt>

		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>

		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>February 2021</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/february-2021/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 02 Feb 2021 00:58:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=664</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"vivid-red","customFontSize":18} -->
<p style="font-size:18px" class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color">Proverbs 22:4, The reward for humility and fear of the LORD is riches and honor and life. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I awoke this morning to learn that one of my childhood heroes, Mr. Henry Louis Aaron, died peacefully in his sleep during the overnight hours. As a lifelong fan of the Atlanta Braves, I remember watching “Hammerin Hank” dig in against the Los Angeles Dodgers’ Al Downing on April 8, 1974. The crowd of 53,775 people in Atlanta Fulton County Stadium stood in anticipation during that 4th inning; a National audience subconsciously leaned-in toward their televisions as Downing’s windup commenced. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ball one. The first pitch to Aaron was down and in the dirt, the kind of pitch a professional throws when sensing he is about to become part of history. Hank had been walked in his first at bat and the crowd sensed more of the same; raucous boos lifted across the sellout crowd. On the next pitch, the left-handed Downing crouched, cocked, and fired a slider. Hank’s eyes must have lit up, a mistake headed his way. "I don't see pitches down the middle anymore - not even in batting practice." </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The slider hung over the plate a bit too long and Hank dispatched it some 385 feet over the left field wall for number 715, surpassing the legendary Babe Ruth’s homerun record. “I knew it was out of the ballpark,” Downing would later say. “It was a line drive. Hank was not a flyball hitter. The difference with Hank and other line drive hitters: His line drives just seemed to carry and carry and carry.” </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p> Most childhood heroes’ long fade: yet Aaron’s legacy transcends time, if anything, more shined today in our remembrances of him. His was a life lived quietly, giving his best to baseball on and off the field. He said, “I just tried to play the game the way it was supposed to be played.” He served up grace and humility, leading with a quiet influence over a lifetime of service to humanity. In recent weeks, Aaron received the COVID-19 vaccine, speaking about wanting to reassure people of color, and to do his part to slow the virus's spread. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On that evening in April, as Hank rounded second base at 9:10PM, two young and overly enthusiastic men sprung from the stands and ran towards Hank, eventually reaching him and celebrating alongside him, pounding him over and over again on the shoulders. Hank continued onward; all the while, Aaron’s bodyguard froze, unsure, pistol pulled from its holster and trained upon the men, watching every footfall. Such was the imminent danger to a humble man doing what he was born to do, what he loved, in the deep south. It was the thin line between adoration and hatred. No. 44 walked both sides. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>One of my favorite quotes from Hank is this: “Well, the pitcher has got only a ball. I’ve got a bat. So, the percentage of weapons is in my favor, and I let the fellow with the ball do the fretting.” </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I am not alone this morning in my memories of Hank Aaron. Our world aches for men, and women, of such stature, walking humbly, quietly going about their work. What we remember of Hank is, of course, lore. But it is also more than that, perhaps far greater influence and honor is given to him – and deservedly so - because of the manner in which he strode after he hung up the cleats. Remaining simple. Quiet. Humble. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Earlier today President Biden issued a statement from the White House, concluding with this: “As a nation, we will still chase the better version of ourselves that he set for us.” Audubon, my prayer is that we would be a people of which it may be said, He has shown you, O mortal, what is good. And what does the LORD require of you? To act justly and to love mercy and to walk humbly with your God. The testimony of such lives goes beyond our wisp-like moments. Even for heroes. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>All of us can chose humility. Let’s allow the others do the fretting. The reward for humility and fear of the LORD is riches and honor and life. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Blessings to you, Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":665,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Front-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Front-Page.pdf">Front Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Front-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":666,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Back-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Back-Page.pdf">Back Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Back-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":667,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Calendar.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Calendar.pdf">Calendar</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/02/Calendar.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>664</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2021-02-02 00:58:51]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>

							</item>
					<item>
		<title>March 2021</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/march-2021/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 02 Mar 2021 21:34:54 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=674</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"align":"center"} -->
<h3 style="text-align:center"><a><strong>Your Influence for Jesus</strong></a></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"textColor":"very-dark-gray"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-very-dark-gray-color"><strong>But you are a chosen race, a royal priesthood, a holy nation, a people for his own possession, that you may proclaim the excellencies of him who called you out of darkness into his marvelous light.   1 Peter 2:9</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have been already thinking about our
Easter celebration and the church universal’s remembrance of Jesus’ victory
over death.&nbsp; On April 4<sup>th</sup>,
Christians from many tongues, from every community of America, across many
denominations, devout Believers and those less so, those that gather weekly for
worship and those that attend biannually, will gather together on Resurrection
Sunday.&nbsp;&nbsp; The day will present us an
opportunity unlike most others, not only to shower love upon guests gathered in
our sanctuary, but also that we may go further, that we might proclaim the
excellencies of Him who called us out of darkness and into His marvelous
light.&nbsp; The sovereign timing of Easter as
related to COVID weariness makes me ponder God’s mysterious ways.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Researchers are confidently documenting increasing Gospel
receptivity as COVID lingers.&nbsp; There is a
principle that is put forth during trials, “The more disruptive a life event is
to a person’s psychological equilibrium, the more it will cause him or her to
be spiritually receptive.”&nbsp; Through the
testimonies of many, we can surely affirm the disruptive reality of COVID;
nothing is as it was thirteen short months ago.&nbsp;
The Corona virus has impacted everyone.&nbsp;
Yet, time is short; before long, we will return towards normal and
restabilize in our equilibriums.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>All of us who call Audubon home are influencers.&nbsp; Each and every one of us have family and
friends and coworkers and neighbors and coffee shop baristas and others God has
placed in front of us.&nbsp;&nbsp; We see them
often.&nbsp; We talk on the phone and share social
media too.&nbsp; They pour our coffee and walk
by us in the neighborhood.&nbsp; We fret over some
because they are precious to us.&nbsp; God has
made each of them in His image.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Because of them, I long
to see the story of His holy nation growing through us.&nbsp; I long to see more of them brought into the
light, finding a love more wondrous than understood, freed from the bondage of
sins that ensnare, and finding peace while sitting among us in the pews.&nbsp; We each have a part to play in proclaiming
His excellencies.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Numerous studies have
been conducted spanning decades – studies that document people finding eternal
life and church homes, churches where they can be loved and grown as
disciples.&nbsp; Consider the results of one
survey in capturing statistics concerning those visiting churches.&nbsp; Of those visiting, </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>2% visited because of an advertisement or
mailer. </li><li>6% visited due to a pastoral invitation.</li><li>6% visited as the result of a church
evangelism campaign, a program.</li><li>86% visited because they were invited by
family or friends.&nbsp; </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastors receive more
than a few suggestions on the top 3.&nbsp; A
more effective question before us all is: “Who will I, who will you, invite to
church?”&nbsp; We understand from latest
statistics that only 17% of churchgoers will ever invite another to
church.&nbsp; 17%.&nbsp; Ever.&nbsp;
Such statistics should shake our sense of equilibrium for the sake of
those we love.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Opportunities
necessarily change during certain eras and historic moments; we will not have
an Easter cantata this year, but we will have a very special service,
nonetheless.&nbsp; We are a people of His own
possession that hold sway and influence over many and can beautifully proclaim
His excellencies.&nbsp; He has entrusted us
with much, including His very Gospel that longs for our telling and sharing
with those we love.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I will be preaching in
March and a good portion of April, including the Passion Week services. &nbsp;I ask for your prayers as we consider those
services. I ask for your prayers concerning who you might invite to visit our
church.&nbsp; I ask for your prayers that we
will make much of the opportunities before us in sharing His beautiful story of
grace.&nbsp; And I will be praying for you
too.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>May God be glorified in us!  Grace, grace, all of it, grace.  Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":679,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-front-page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-front-page.pdf">MAR front page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-front-page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":680,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-back-page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-back-page.pdf">MAR back page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-back-page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":681,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-calendar.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-calendar.pdf">MAR calendar</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/MAR-calendar.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>674</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2021-03-02 21:34:54]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2021-03-02 21:34:54]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[march-2021]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>April 2021</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/april-2021/</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 01 Apr 2021 14:48:45 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=694</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a><strong>A New Beginning</strong></a><strong></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em><strong>John 20:2, So she came running to Simon Peter and the other disciple, the one Jesus loved, and said, “They have taken the Lord out of the tomb, and we don’t know where they have put Him!”</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Most of us will remember our grade school days and recess.&nbsp; I smile recalling a girl that taunted all the
boys in the 4th grade.&nbsp; Samantha.&nbsp; Samantha was tall and slender and kind and
fun and all smiles with her braces, but more than that, she was fast, blazing
fast in comparison to every boy in our school.&nbsp;
One after another, the boys, myself included, would toe the line during
recess to race her around the playground.&nbsp;
On your mark, get set, GO!&nbsp; One by
one she would dispense with us, giggling and offering another try, “see you
tomorrow”. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As Easter morning dawned, Jesus’ closest friends were downtrodden
and mourning the finality of His life and ministry.&nbsp; Unsteadiness reigned as if time stood
still.&nbsp; What held incredible wonder in
recent days with the resurrection of Lazarus and the Triumphal Entry now felt long
in the past, blurred among Friday’s events.&nbsp;
Jesus’ closest friends were paralyzed in time, unsure of which direction
their lives would take.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Imagine them.&nbsp; Everything
seemed in order and purposeful one moment, and in the span of one short week,
they were lost.&nbsp; Such is the journey of
faithful followers of Christ.&nbsp; In our
lives, there are times that we are on the pathway we intend, we hope for, marching
straight ahead toward our calling or goal, and absolutely nothing can force our
sidestep.&nbsp; Then, something, that
something, well it causes us to become paralyzed in our forward progress, stalled, and stuck.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; We question: What shall I do now?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We feel the anguish and confusion of Jesus’ disciples and those
closest to Him when we read the accounts.&nbsp;
Suddenly, there seems little to do other than tend the tomb and hide out
from the authorities who were still combing the city looking for them. &nbsp;This is not what they thought, certainly not
what they dreamed when enlisting. &nbsp;In a
moment, everything changed for this Unfinished
group of Believers.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In Chapter 20 of John’s Gospel, we find those closest to Jesus
running.&nbsp; Mary Magdalene is going through
the paces of caring for her dear friend as she approaches the tomb.&nbsp; Suddenly, something seems awry and bothered
and she sets off running.&nbsp; She is Unfinished in her understanding of
Jesus’ words; she runs to get the others so that they can handle the
situation.&nbsp; <strong><em>They have taken the
Lord out of the tomb, and we don’t know where they have put Him!</em></strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In one of the great jabs of Scripture, John reports that the “other
disciple” (John) outraced Peter to the tomb.&nbsp;
Even in the blur of the moment John reports the race results! The
disciples look inside the tomb and find the burial clothes neatly folded,
separate from the strips of linen.&nbsp; Jesus
is orderly and purposeful while resurrecting from the dead and leaving the
tomb.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>John enters the tomb first; <strong><em>He saw and believed. </em></strong>But
keep reading and don’t miss verse 20:9, “up until seeing, <strong><em>They still did
not understand from the Scripture that Jesus had to rise from the dead.</em></strong>&nbsp; We see once again that these closest friends
of Jesus are struggling to see it all, to understand fully, their Lord.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are times in our lives that we must simply do the next thing,
finding refuge in the fact that we cannot yet fully understand and see the way
forward.&nbsp; While such times can be
unsteadying, we can be assured that we remain His children and He extends to us
<strong><em>grace upon grace.&nbsp; </em></strong>I am so
thankful.<strong><em></em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Easter morning set in motion "A New Beginning" for those unfinished friends of Jesus.  While they didn’t understand what that morning would hold, when they didn’t have clarity regarding how their lives would go, everything changed.  These faithful followers of Christ were doing their best, even without understanding, even while unfinished.  And everything changed.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We cannot be certain of the days ahead.&nbsp; But this we know, we are His children and He
loves us, and because of that truth, the rest shall be okay.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Grace upon grace,</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":702,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Front-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Front-Page.pdf">Front Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Front-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":704,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Back-Page.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Back-Page.pdf">Back Page</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Back-Page.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":705,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Calendar.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Calendar.pdf">Calendar</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/04/Calendar.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>694</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2021-04-01 14:48:45]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2021-04-01 14:48:45]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[april-2021]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>May 2021</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/may-2021/</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 02 May 2021 11:52:42 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=722</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","fontSize":"medium"} -->
<p style="text-align:center" class="has-medium-font-size"> <strong>PERFECT LOVE CASTS OUT FEAR</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","textColor":"vivid-red"} -->
<p style="text-align:center" class="has-text-color has-vivid-red-color"><strong><em> 1 John 4:18, There is not fear in love, but perfect  love casts out fear.</em></strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>On Friday, April 23rd, we handed over one of the  giants of our faith to life everlasting in the presence  of the Father and the Son.  Dr. Edgar Hatfield is safely  home and has heard His Savior confess his name to  the Father and the angels.  What a moment; what a joyful anticipation for us that still sojourn.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I have thought back to the last time that I was with  Eddie.  A few days before he went home to Jesus, I  was able to worship with him one more time.  We sang and we prayed, and we talked. It seemed clear that Eddie was drawing close in his physical body, but his spiritual presence remained as vibrant and alive as  any other time I sat with him.  He was worshipful,  smiling, and content in his soul and relationships, most importantly, his relationship with Jesus.  As I heard him pray one farewell benediction, I thought, this must surely be as close as possible to what was said of Moses, <em>The LORD would speak to Moses face to  face, as one speaks to a friend. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Even in those hours, Eddie taught me through his  example.  It was to my great benefit to be his friend  in these last years, and sit at his feet one last time, my elder in the faith showing me how the last lap of this  earthly life should be run.  I observed my brother  softly sing the hymns for well over an hour with  fullness of joy; I felt his hospitality to me, a guest, within his home during a time of physical suffering; I heard him reminisce for the fellowship of the Saints, longing to see you; I sensed his acceptance of, as the Apostle Paul wrote, <em>For to me, to live is Christ and to die is gain</em>; I also saw and heard and realized that a son is  never ready, regardless of circumstances, to let go of a father who has done his best, even when he goes to  the arms of Christ.  We will always long for more. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>But there is one more thing I learned from Eddie, and witnessed during my visit, that exemplifies our study of First John -perfect love casts out fear.  We have read John repetitively point us towards loving one  another, not just as a proof point for our faith, but  also because we have been bought by the blood of  Christ.  We have been crucified with Christ.  It is no  longer we who live, but Christ who lives in us. Eddie loved us well. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Since Friday, I have heard testimonies from members of our church, listened in  on personal voicemails, read emails from some outside our church, reviewed posts on social media,  and reread the letters he wrote to me. And here’s  the thing – they all say some version of, “Eddie was  for me. He encouraged me often, especially when… He loved me so well.”  I heard these memories from  many of you, from his peers to those in the middle,  even letters received by Audubon’s children.  Each demonstrated love in a tangible, life giving way.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Eddie was as well credentialed as a pastor can be, educated and achieved in four Biblical and seminary degrees.  Yet, it was his immeasurable love for the Saints of Audubon and elsewhere that shall prove his  enduring legacy. We will remember his love. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Each of us get to choose how we will be remembered; the choice is ours alone. Regardless of our backgrounds and circumstances, we can demonstrate that we learned how to love well.  I endeavor to follow his lead; I pray that you will join me. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We thank our God in all remembrance of him,  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastor Jeff </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":723,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Newsletter-May-2021-Front-Page.pdf"} -->

<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- /wp:file -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":725,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/Calendar-2021-May.pdf"} -->

<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>

					<item>
		<title>June 2021</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/june-2021/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 31 May 2021 22:06:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=741</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p style="text-align:center"><strong>Cooperating for His Glory </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p style="text-align:center">I planted, Apollos watered, but God gave the growth. 1 Corinthians 3:6</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Since our founding in 1944, Audubon Baptist has aligned our mission with the Southern Baptist Convention. We cooperate with the convention, holding to the same tenants of the faith once for all delivered to the Saints, seeking to reach the world with the Good News of Jesus Christ.  We believe in the mission. And we join with like-minded churches so that the Word of the Lord may speed ahead and be honored (2 Thessalonians 3:1).  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I appreciate the convention and the heart behind cooperating for the Gospel. Cooperation recognizes that each has a role to play, but it is God that gives the increase and growth, for His glory and sovereign purposes. I am committed to cooperation, with the convention and locally too. It comforts me that Audubon stands with more than fifty thousand sister churches, with no two churches exactly alike. Our churches represent every corner of our nation, ranging in size from micro to mega – for awareness, Audubon is typical in size. Some worship traditionally, using organs, like us. Others worship in a more contemporary style, with a whole ensemble of instruments, singing a new song unto the Lord. Despite our differences, we cooperate in unity, standing upon the framework of historic Biblical orthodoxy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We regularly hear the word diversity bantered about in our day. Here too, Southern Baptists lead the way and shine through cooperation. Our churches represent many races and ethnicities – African American, Caucasian, Chinese, Hispanic, Korean, Native American, Russian, and many more. On a typical Sunday morning, over 100 native languages are spoken in our churches - in the United States! One would be hard pressed to uncover any constituency group, anywhere in the world, with more reach and breath in diversity than our 15M members represent. SBC churches do ministry in sanctuaries like ours, and storefronts, and in parks, and in office buildings too; there are even a few motorcycle congregations. Each one is a part of the SBC and cooperate and contribute to a fuller portrait of the bride of Christ. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The SBC holds its convention annually. Members come together, representing local churches, arriving as diverse races, ethnicities, socio-economic statuses, languages, and congregational sizes. Cooperating churches mutually elect officers, decide governance, seek unity and means to further the Gospel. The convention is a picture of the day we shall all gather before the throne, churches made ready for Christ, called from every corner of the globe.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This year’s convention will be held in Nashville, June 15 and 16. The convention is open to all and requires a simple registration. You are invited. Lord willing, Audubon will have representation by several at the convention.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For those unable to attend the convention, some ask, “what can we do to support it?” We can pray. I cheered when Pastor J.D. Greear (62nd President of the SBC) called upon our fifty thousand churches to pray. Prayer is accessible to each of us. We are great commission Baptists and that requires that we be a people of prayer.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In this Newsletter, you will find several “Prayer Guides”. We will be praying over these Wednesday evenings. Will you also commit to praying with me during the week? The areas of prayer are targeted and specific, each serving a purpose in speeding His Word to the nations. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Each of us is important. Just what might our great God do when we join together in prayer, cooperating with 15M other brothers and sisters, for His glory? One thing is certain - it shall be glorious! </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>With thanksgiving, Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:file {"id":742,"href":"https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/ABC-June-Newsletter.pdf"} -->
<div class="wp-block-file"><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/ABC-June-Newsletter.pdf">Complete June Newsletter</a><a href="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/05/ABC-June-Newsletter.pdf" class="wp-block-file__button" download>Download</a></div>
<!-- /wp:file -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

							</item>
					<item>
		<title>July 2021</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/july-2021/</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Jun 2021 19:14:10 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=764</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p style="text-align:center"><strong>Consumerism in the Church House of God</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p style="text-align:center"><em>And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.  Acts 2:42 </em> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It seems that increasingly time wins its sprinting race.  Moments in recent history that I studied in school as a young child are now decades and decades ‘back then’.  I often try to explain this phenomenon of time to my children, beginning, “You just wait” …  I suppose each must learn these shared commonalities about time as we age.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Within recent months, we surpassed the sixty-year mark since our country inaugurated the first Catholic president in our history.  In that day, many were concerned that John F. Kennedy’s Catholicism would overrun the White House and his impartial decision-making on behalf of all citizens.  Some conjectured that a predominantly Protestant nation was slipping away, and the Pope would increasingly direct the political winds in our country.  Tensions ran high on January 20, 1961; like in our day, America was indeed a closely divided country.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Temperatures were in the lower 20s that morning as the president-elect rose from his seat to take the oath of office against a backdrop of deep snow.  Having removed his topcoat, he projected youth and vigor as he placed his hand upon the Fitzgerald family Bible, becoming our nation’s 35<sup>th</sup> president.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Following the oath, President Kennedy turned and approached the lectern, ready to address the nation.  Those familiar with his preparations recalled how the president wanted to be inspirational yet brief, remarking to a close advisor, “I don’t want people to think I’m a windbag.”  His speech was modeled significantly after  Lincoln’s Gettysburg Address, utilizing catch phrases meant to grab the hearer’s attention.  One such phrase stands alone,    </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>“And so, my fellow Americans: ask not what your country can do for you—ask what you can do for your country.” </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The sentence spoken by the new president came late in the short speech, calling fellow Americans beyond themselves, beseeching them to pursue service and sacrifice.  I was not alive when the words were spoken; yet I know them by heart, they shape me, and they drive me forward.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The speech by the young president called Americans past lifestyles, and emotional expectations too, of <em>Consumerism</em>.  A majority have befriended consumerism in our day too and look to the offerings of government through our personal lens.  We expect politicians to serve it up in language that suits our individual hopes and wants, and so they do.  As President Kennedy identified, such ‘me-ism’, if left unattended, eventually builds a society which collapses upon itself, with a people chronically dissatisfied.  The ability to sustain ever increasing expectations of ever-increasing blessing is fantastical and cannot be delivered.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Unfortunately, if not purposely attentive, <em>Consumerism</em> invades the church house too.  We may be prone to think, even demand, what does church have for me in this area or that?  We may fall into the temptation of seeing the church as primarily an institution delivering our needs, our hopes, our dreams.  As most pastors attest, the typical call from someone considering visiting a church often begins with such a question:  What do you have for me (or my family) in the area of _______(fill in the blank)?  We’ve gotten things a bit out of order as God’s people.  Clearly, the theme of President Kennedy’s address still resonates.  We can do better as Christ’ universal church.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We must push <em>Consumeristic</em> thoughts aside and stop asking what the church can do for us if the Gospel is to truly achieve prominence within the church house.  If we do not win this tug a war, the sickly symptoms of experientialism, ungratefulness, and jealousy will soon follow, eroding what the church should be in Christ.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Max Lucado summarizes the logical end of ‘me-ism’ in his book, <em>It’s Not About Me: rescue from the Life we thought would make us happy</em> (2011), writing, “They all told us it was about us, didn't they? And we took them up on it. We thought self-celebration would make us happy and satisfied.  But believing that has created chaos -- noisy homes, stress-filled businesses, cutthroat relationships. We've chased so many skinny rabbits, says Max Lucado, that we've missed the God-centered life.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The early church, and healthiest ones in our day too, resist <em>Consumerism </em>with layered rededications and turnings away.  They fashion not their ministry around the latest and greatest growth program, but instead, focus with laser-like intensity on becoming a God-centric people seeking to make His name great and know Him more (Ephesians 4:13).   </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Since 1944, this has been the overarching hallmark of Audubon Baptist, and with God’s favor, shall be as we continue forward.  We purpose to delight in the teachings of the apostles; we shall pursue sweetness in fellowship because we are a people bought by the blood of Christ; we will hold fast to the wonder of Holy Communion; and we will dedicate ourselves to prayer.  Such are to be the main courses of His church, from the earliest church until the time of His return.  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You will hear more in the coming months about these four pillars within our beloved Audubon church and how we intend to strengthen them.  But for now, as we emerge from COVID, these pillars are worthy of our renewed consideration.  I agree with Max.  It is not about me.  It is also not even about us.  It is about Him, the living and resurrected Son, our redeemer, Jesus Christ.  All praise and glory and honor to His name!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Grace upon grace, </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p style="text-align:center"><strong><em>For from His fullness we have all received, grace upon grace.  John 1:16</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>764</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2021-06-30 19:14:10]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2021-06-30 19:14:10]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[open]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[july-2021]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type><![CDATA[post]]></wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password><![CDATA[]]></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
														<wp:postmeta>
		<wp:meta_key><![CDATA[_edit_last]]></wp:meta_key>
		<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
							</item>
					<item>
		<title>August 2021</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/august-2021/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Aug 2021 01:45:34 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?p=788</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p style="text-align:center"><strong>The Missional Church</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p style="text-align:center"><em>But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit has come upon you, and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the end of the earth.  Acts 1:8</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Jesus was preparing to go to the Father.  Following His resurrection, He appeared to the disciples during 40 days, teaching them further about the Kingdom of God.  I imagine these men, going from confusion upon seeing their friend and Lord, to perhaps even getting accustomed to His presence once again among them.  They are told by Jesus that they will be baptized with the Holy Spirit; they ponder what that may mean.  Jesus tells them: <strong>you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the end of the earth.  </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Jesus’ words are straightforward.  They are to wait a bit longer and not to go before they receive power.  Then, they are to go forth and tell others about Jesus with a Spirit-enabled power.  They are to begin with those closest, in a land familiar, before moving outward.  Jesus gives the disciples a mission statement that any corporate America CEO would pay big consulting bucks to develop; it is simple, clear, hope-filled, and attainable.  Jesus is the King of Kings.  He expects obedience and success from these men who were, just a few days prior, hiding behind a locked door.  Utterly afraid.  Their fear is smashed in the presence of Jesus and His mission.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>One of our church’s strategic emphases is that we will be a MISSIONAL people for the Lord Jesus Christ.  We are a people committed to telling others the Good News of the Gospel, available for the whole world, and we will do it beginning with those in closest proximity to us.  When we boil the essence of missions down to its core, it requires our individual faithfulness in all sorts of settings, but importantly, where God has placed us today, for His namesake and glory.  Not all will go to the end of the earth, but all will be a witness where we live, work, and play.  The question before us is this: to what shall we witness?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I am excited to inform you that a team has been working on the “picture” of our church missional emphases for some time now.  We have identified the location of our church “missions wall” (just outside the sanctuary) and work has commenced.  I asked the team to consider these objectives:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>To simplify the picture of Audubon missions so that our church members can understand and be reminded of our priorities upon entering and exiting the sanctuary.  </li><li>To identify the equivalent of Jerusalem, Judea, Samaria, and the end of the earth for our ministry context.  Upon completion of the wall, you will be able to “see” our missional priorities, beginning with Audubon Park and moving outward.  On the wall you will be able to read about our intentionality at Lifehouse / BsideU for Life, Peru, and unreached people groups.  </li><li>To align and communicate our missional priorities in other venues beyond the wall.  You will begin reading missional happenings in future newsletters, as well as experiencing enhanced missions’ focus on select Wednesday evenings.  Each touchpoint is intended to foster awareness and participation among church members within our Audubon missional initiatives.  </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We expect our “missions wall” to be completed within several
months.&nbsp; God has richly blessed Audubon
Baptist Church, most significantly, because we have come to know His Son.&nbsp; Let us endeavor together to make His great
name known, from our sanctuary to the end of the earth. &nbsp;He is worthy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Blessings, Pastor Jeff</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

					<item>
		<title>Brokenness and Waiting</title>
		<link>https://www.achurchinthepark.org/sermon/lamentations-321-30-brokenness-and-waiting/</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 13 Aug 2019 01:01:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[audubon_Church]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.achurchinthepark.org/?post_type=sermons&#038;p=310</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h4>TEXT 3:21-30</h4>
[audio mp3="https://www.achurchinthepark.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/DR0000_0172_1_1.mp3"][/audio]
<h5 class="wp-block-audio" style="text-align: center;">7.21.2019 by Pastor Jeff Akin</h5>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>310</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date><![CDATA[2019-08-13 01:01:57]]></wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt><![CDATA[2019-08-13 01:01:57]]></wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status><![CDATA[closed]]></wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name><![CDATA[lamentations-321-30-brokenness-and-waiting]]></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status><![CDATA[publish]]></wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
